Award.AwardTitle: STEM Context Matters: An Inaugural Conference of the DMV MSI STEM Alliance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers from Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) are seriously under-represented in NSF funded research activities. This is a serious problem given the increasing diversity of the US workforce and the need to expand the STEM workforce. This proposed founding conference will bring researchers from 12 MSIs in the DMV area to form a research alliance among researchers in these institutions, discuss obstacles to increased research output and how best to improve STEM research and education in these institutions. The conference will discuss and establish a research coordination platform across these institutions with advisory board and a management committee. The conference will also establish collaborative research teams across these institutions. The organizers plan several follow-up conferences to evaluate progress as well as adjust strategies to get to their objectives. This conference will not only help increase the participation of MSI researchers in NSF funded SBE research activities; it will also help to expand and diversify the STEM workforce, thus increasing economic growth.


This conference proposal responds to NSF Social Behavioral and Economics (SBE) Directorateâ€™s Build and Broaden initiative to increase participation of researchers from MSIs in NSF funded STEM research and educational activities. The proposed founding conference will bring researchers from 12 MSIs together to form a research alliance and discuss current obstacles to research productivity in their institutions and how best to increase research activities and improve STEM education in these institutions. The proposed conference will discuss new ideas and solutions to low research productivity in MSIs and could have transformative effects on research and STEM education in these institutions. The alliance to be formed at the conference as well as solutions to research problems could also serve as a blueprint for other groups of MSIs to follow to increase research productivity as well as improve STEM education. This conference will help increase the participation of MSI researchers in NSF funded SBE research activities as well as help to expand and diversify the STEM workforce, thus increasing economic growth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
STEM Context Matters: An Inaugural Conference of the DMV MSI STEM Alliance

Morgan State University

STEM Context Matters (SCM) (DUE- 2037432) was funded as a conference grant awarded to Morgan State University with the goal of convening a community of STEM researchers and STEM social and behavioral (SBE) scientists to establish the HBCU STEM Alliance, a network of STEM researchers and STEM social and behavioral scientists at Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) in the md-Atlantic region. We hosted a virtual conference in 2021, one in-person conference in 2022 and six virtual working group sessions in 2021 and 2022. Data from a barriers and facilitators survey was used to inform project activities. Results from this survey informed the decision to include staff and administrators from the office of sponsored programs and research (OSPR), department chairs and senior administrators to participate in the second conference. Coaches were hired to advise the faculty participants in the development of their proposals, and experienced presenters supported faculty in understanding NSF grant solicitations and crafting winning proposals. Conference participants were provided the time and space to network, seek opportunities for collaboration and work on their proposals.

As we began to build this community, we encountered two initial challenges in recruiting participants.  One there is a lack of awareness of the NSF SBE directorate and how social scientists could leverage their research for funding, since NSF focuses on funding research in the STEM disciplines such as biology, mathematics, and STEM education. A second challenge was the limited availability of graduate programs in SBE disciplines at HBCUs, which limited the pool of scholars who trained graduate students and have reduced teaching loads, which can be barriers to effective grantsmanship.

Results from conference discussions and presentations, virtual chat discussions, barriers and facilitators survey results, assessment, and post-conference survey uncovered significant gaps in participants’ knowledge regarding policies, practices, processes, and procedures relating to proposal submission and grant management. Participants who have submitted unsuccessful applications for NSF funding reported never having heard of the Proposal & Award Policies & Procedures Guide (PAPPG). Similarly, other faculty members who have submitted unsuccessful applications for NSF-funded reported being unaware that proposals have an evaluation component. Participants overwhelmingly reported being unaware of the expansive range of NSF funding opportunities and resources available to them. Participants also reported a lack of infrastructure within their institutions to support a submission to the NSF. Besides knowledge, participants also identified a need for a system and/or strategy for PIs to be able to identify PIs within their institutions and at other minority-serving institutions (MSIs) to collaborate. Administrative leaders including deans and sponsored programs officials reported leaving the conference with a better understanding of the experience of faculty writing a grant and navigating the submission process and vowed to return to their institutions and refine support and resources for faculty. The convenings and surveys also revealed the needs of faculty within institutions, such as professional development, the onboarding process for new faculty members, time, and material and personnel resources that would support them in conducting research. And, finally, the conference, virtual sessions, and surveys advanced questions about ways in which the NSF might expand the breadth of its marketing and representation so that SBE scientists are more aware of NSF funding opportunities, increase grant development training for potential PIs, and provide technical assistance to institutions to improves their processes for grant development and submission.

Forty-eight participants participated in the June 2022 SCM in-person conference. Twenty-eight of 48 participants responded to the survey, a 58% response rate. Overall, 82% of 28 survey respondents rated the conference content highly or very highly. Sixty-eight percent of 28 survey respondents were highly or very highly satisfied with the planning and organization of the conference. Differences among conference participants were found among novice and veteran proposers for grant funding. More novices (N=13) reported being highly or very highly satisfied with the meeting materials and resources (92%) compared to 15 veterans (64%) and with the audiovisual and presentation technology (75% of novices vs. 57% of veterans). Novices were new to proposal work and welcomed any information, perhaps regardless of the medium, they are delivered. The workshops, in-person and virtual conferences, and related resources generated from the convenings have also contributed to building participants’ knowledge and awareness of the overall NSF grant process and the SBE Directorate program requirements specifically. These convenings have also facilitated deeper conversations among MSI faculty members and their respective office of sponsored research staff members on how they can coordinate and partner together to improve the chances that the MSI will be awarded a competitive grant based on their faculty members’ proposals. A manuscript highlighting the findings from the project and the facilitators and barriers survey will be submitted for publication in May 2024.
